etymologies: early 19th century (in the sense ‘relating to human beings’): from Greek anthrōpikos, from anthrōpos ‘human being’: the second sense may also be interpreted as a shortening of anthropogenic

definitions: (in philosophy and cosmology) involving or concerning the existence of human life, especially as a constraint on theories of the universe

examples.text: anthropic reasoning is only interesting in a scientific sense if it can help us understand how the universe came to be the way it is

definitions: (typically of environmental degradation) caused by human beings; anthropogenic
